title: 1930's Saturday Evening Post banner font.
content: I'm looking for the font from the 1930's Norman Rockwell era Saturday Evening Post which was used in their masthead. Anyone have a name or know where I can find it?
author: myarchie08

comments.content: Custom by [Guernsey Moore](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155353/http:/www.curtispublishing.com/bios/Moore.shtml). There's a digital font in the same style called [Saturday Morning Toast](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155353/http:/myfonts.us/td-4pg5W5) (Nick Curtis, 2001).

If you are talking about the two-line nameplate that ran the full width of the cover, it was most likely hand-drawn—not a typeface. That particular nameplate actually dates from the very early 1900s and was used for decades.

American Type Founders did release a typeface called Curtis Post in 1902. It was based on Post Oldstyle Roman No. 2, which was the model for hand-lettered headings in the magazine at the time:  
 [http://luc.devroye.org/fonts-71374.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155353/http:/luc.devroye.org/fonts-71374.html "http://luc.devroye.org/fonts-71374.html")  
 [http://luc.devroye.org/EJKitson-or-GuernseyMoore-or-HermannIhlenburg--Po...](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155353/http:/luc.devroye.org/EJKitson-or-GuernseyMoore-or-HermannIhlenburg--PostOldstyleRomanNo2--1901.png "http://luc.devroye.org/EJKitson-or-GuernseyMoore-or-HermannIhlenburg--PostOldstyleRomanNo2--1901.png")

There are a few digital “tribute” typefaces:  
 [https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/saturday-morning-toast/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155353/https:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/saturday-morning-toast/ "https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/saturday-morning-toast/")  
 [https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/jnlevine/lamp-post/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155353/https:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/jnlevine/lamp-post/ "https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/jnlevine/lamp-post/")

Another typeface from that era that is very similar is Windsor:  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/windsor-mt/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155353/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/windsor-mt/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/windsor-mt/")

I'm not a fan of the "rugged" style of lettering used in the masthead -- but if you are a fan of distressed and antique lettering styles, your mileage will differ.  
I prefer the polished version made by Nick Curtis.  
For searchers of authentic versions of the letterhead the I concur in the posted information on Curtis Post of 1902 and Post Oldstyle Roman No. 2.  
Every major foundry of circa 1900 produced similar "rugged" rounded letter fonts of similar weight. If there is any interest I will post a list.  
Don.
Thanks, Don, I’d be interested in that list.

OK Kevin, I will do a round-up of the usual suspects.  
Don

First is Buffalo, a popular typeface in the early 20th century by the H.C.Hansen foundry:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155353im_/http:/typophile.com/files/HansenCharsetSM_5694.jpg)
  
Virtually identical typeface sold in Europe as Kolonial. No digital.  
Don

Second is Blanchard Inland -- a font from Inland Type foundry circa 1900. digitized by Paulo W [http://www.dafont.com/blanchard-inland.font?text=Saturday+Evening+Post](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155353/http:/www.dafont.com/blanchard-inland.font?text=Saturday+Evening+Post "http://www.dafont.com/blanchard-inland.font?text=Saturday+Evening+Post")  
Don

Third is Wood Stevens Bold -- a font digitized by Paulo W [http://www.dafont.com/wood-stevens-bold.font?text=Saturday+Evening+Post&...](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155353/http:/www.dafont.com/wood-stevens-bold.font?text=Saturday+Evening+Post&fpp=100 "http://www.dafont.com/wood-stevens-bold.font?text=Saturday+Evening+Post&fpp=100")  
Don

Tom Carnase and Ronne Bonder used Post Oldstyle as the basis for ITC Gorilla.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155353im_/http:/typophile.com/files/ITCGorillaAsSatEvgPost_6166.gif)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/itc-gorilla/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155353/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/itc-gorilla/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/itc-gorilla/")  
Don

Updated:  
ATF's Hearst, digitized by Nick Curtis as Ragged Write NF

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155353im_/http:/typophile.com/files/RaggedWriteNFAsSatEvgPost_6121.gif)
http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/ragged-write-nf/  
Also digitized by Richard Kegler as P22 Kane 
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155353im_/http:/typophile.com/files/P22KaneAsSatEvgPost_4600.gif)
https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/p22/kane/  
Don

F.W. Goudy's Powell of 1903

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155353im_/http:/typophile.com/files/GoudyPowell1903@85pct_5994.jpg)
 Produced by the Keystone Foundry as a commission for a Mr. Powell, who was working at the time as advertising manager for the Mandel Brothers. Powell had previously commissioned a font for another company. That font became Pabst Old Style, as shown in the ATF 1906 catalog. A digital version  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155353im_/http:/typophile.com/files/LTCPabstOldStyleAsSatEvgPost_5814.gif)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/lanston/ltc-pabst-oldstyle/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155353/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/lanston/ltc-pabst-oldstyle/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/lanston/ltc-pabst-oldstyle/")  
Don

Inland produced a condensed version of Pabst Oldstyle, which appeared, with the name Avil, in the 1912 ATF catalog.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155353im_/http:/typophile.com/files/AvilInlandSM2_4899.jpg)
  
Don

Updated:  
Barnhardt Brothers and Spindler had Plymouth in their 1907 catalog

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155353im_/http:/typophile.com/files/BBS-1907-Plymouth-72ptASM_5990.jpg)
 It was digitized [rather too roughly] by Rick Mueller in 1999  
 [http://www.fontspace.com/rick-mueller/plymouth](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155353/http:/www.fontspace.com/rick-mueller/plymouth "http://www.fontspace.com/rick-mueller/plymouth")  
BB&S also had a condensed version 
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155353im_/http:/typophile.com/files/BBS-1907-PlymouthCondensed-60ptASM_3790.jpg)
  
Don
